title: 103_hr107
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Congressional Accountability Act of 1993". The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 applies laws related to employment terms, health and safety, and employer-employee rights to Congress, similar to how they apply to private individuals and Executive agencies. The specified laws include the Social Security Act and the National Labor Relations Act. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 applies various laws to Congress, including the Social Security Act, National Labor Relations Act, Fair Labor Standards Act, Civil Rights Act, Age Discrimination in Employment Act, Occupational Safety and Health Act, Title IX, Rehabilitation Act, Privacy Act, Age Discrimination Act, Ethics in Government Act, and Americans with Disabilities Act. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 applies various laws to Congress, including the Privacy Act of 1974, Age Discrimination Act of 1975, Ethics in Government Act of 1978, and Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990. Congress is subject to the Freedom of Information Act and Independent Counsel Provisions. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 applies to Congress, including provisions from title 28, United States Code related to independent counsel. It covers Senators, Representatives, employees of Congress, elected officers, Capitol Police, and employees of Members. Employees covered under the Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 include elected officers, Legislative Counsel, Capitol Police, employees of Members whose pay is handled by specific offices, and employees of various Congressional instrumentalities. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 covers employees of various Congressional instrumentalities, including the Government Printing Office, the Library of Congress, the Congressional Budget Office, and the Copyright Royalty Tribunal. It also addresses the treatment of employees in the district or State office of a Member, allowing consideration of political affiliation and place of residence for staff employment. Additionally, a conforming amendment repeals Section 509 of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990. The Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 is amended to allow consideration of political affiliation and place of residence for staff employment on the personal staff of a Member of Congress. Additionally, a small business exemption applies to Members based on the number of employees necessary to qualify as a small business. SEC. 3. PROMULGATION OF IMPLEMENTING REGULATIONS.

Within 180 days of this Act's enactment, the House of Representatives and the Senate must create rules to implement the Act, in line with Federal law. Failure to do so will result in being subject to Executive agency regulations.

SEC. 4. RIGHT OF APPEAL.

Individuals affected by actions under this Act can seek review in a Federal district court, with rights and remedies as private persons under relevant laws.
